I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will strengthen Mongolia’s climate 
change adaptation capacity and community resilience to climate change through three outputs 
designed to build the knowledge and capacity of the Climate Change Research and Cooperation 
Center (CCRCC) under the Ministry of Environment and Tourism (MET), support integration of 
Mongolia’s Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC) into policies and projects, and improve 
engagement of civil society in climate change adaptation initiatives.1 The TA is included in the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) country operations business plan for Mongolia, 2021.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Socioeconomic profile and climate-related risks. Mongolia is extremely vulnerable to 
the effects of climate change, ranked 67th out of 181 in the 2020 ND-GAIN Index.3 It is also among 
the most heavily coal-dependent countries in Asia. Greenhouse gas emissions come primarily 
from  the  energy  (50.1%)  and  agriculture  (48.5%)  sectors.  Greenhouse  gas  emissions  are 
projected to increase from 25.8 million tons of carbon dioxide in 2010 to 74.3 million tons by 2030 
in a business-as-usual scenario.4 From 1940 to 2015, average temperatures increased by 2.2°C, 
triple the global average and already beyond the 2°C set by the Paris Agreement to limit global 
warming.5 Since 1940, annual precipitation has decreased by 7%, seasonal rainfall patterns have 
become erratic,6 and the frequency of extreme weather events such as dzud has increased.7 
 
3.  Climate  change  impacts.  Climate  change  and  environmental  degradation  present 
severe risks to (i) water resources management, (ii) biodiversity conservation and ecosystem 
restoration, and (iii) tourism. Because of the increase in average national temperatures, water 
resources have become more vulnerable to droughts; from 2005 to 2015, about 600 lakes dried 
up (footnote 5). Glacier loss in Mongolia, estimated at 28% since 1940, is expected to continue 
with the increase in frequency and severity of heatwaves. Water-related disaster risks, including 
river and flash flooding, are increasing. Flash flooding alone accounted for 24% of deaths caused 
by natural hazards between 2004 and 2015 (footnote 5). Projected climate changes will also have 
key implications for biodiversity and ecosystems threatening Mongolia’s protected areas, such as 
the Khuvsgul Lake National Park.8 The combined impacts of climate change and overgrazing is 
also contributing to the decline of pasture productivity and herding livelihoods. For tourism, climate 
change may result in greater damage to infrastructure (such as roads and camps), increased 
operation costs for running tourism infrastructure, and decreased number of visitors. Climate 
change also disproportionally impacts vulnerable rural communities, especially women and youth, 
who have fewer options for income diversification and other approaches to help offset the impacts 
of climate change.

4.  Capacity and institutional challenges to address climate change adaptation. In 
collaboration  with  key  development  partners,9 the  government  has  launched  the  National 
Adaptation  Plan  process. 10  To  enable  cooperation  and  coordination  among  concerned 
government agencies, private business entities and local environmental civil society organizations’ 
(CSO), the CCRCC was established under the MET in 2020. The CCRCC’s mandate is to ensure 
implementation  of  Mongolia’s  climate  policies  and  its  NDC  commitments  under  the  Paris 
Agreement, by (i) conducting research, (ii) providing strategic guidance, (iii) promoting civil society 
initiatives, and (iv) piloting innovative solutions from the private sector. However, three main 
issues constrain CCRCC’s ability to deliver on its mandate and be fully operational. As a newly 
established and self-funded state-owned enterprise, CCRCC lacks (i) the financial and technical 
capacity11 to conduct effective climate risk assessments and report on NDC adaptation actions; 
(ii) strategic coordination and planning ability across line ministries on adaptation measures and 
climate finance reporting in the natural resources sector;12 and (iii) mechanisms, selection criteria, 
and monitoring tools to engage with local environmental CSOs to support local adaptation and 
resilience initiatives.13  
 
5.  Government strategy and focus on climate change adaptation. The government has 
adopted a series of policies to mitigate and adapt to climate change. These include the National 
Action Program on Climate Change (2011–2021),14 the National Green Development Policy 
(2014–2030),15 and Sustainable Development Vision 2030.16 In 2020, the government submitted 
its updated NDCs with a higher mitigation target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 22.7% 
by 2030.17 The government has also finalized the NDC implementation plan, which prioritizes 
sector-specific mitigation and adaptation measures (footnote 4). Areas of national priority for 
adaptation  planning  in  Mongolia  include  arable  farming,  water  and  forestry  resources 
management,  and  biodiversity.18 National  efforts  to  strengthen  climate  change  adaptation 
measures and targets will also be key to achieving Mongolia’s obligations as a signatory to the 
Paris Agreement and following the 26th United Nations Climate Change Conference on Climate 
in 2021. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
6.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: adaptation and resilience to climate risks in 
Mongolia improved (footnote 15). The TA will have the following outcome: government’s strategic 
planning capacity for climate change adaptation in the environment and natural resources sector 
improved and resilience of communities to climate change strengthened.19 The outcome of the 
TA will be achieved by delivering the following interlinked outputs.

B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
7.  Output 1: Climate Change Research and Cooperation Center capacity to manage 
climate change risks and strategic planning enhanced. Under output 1, activities will include: 
(i) develop a strategic business and action plan to improve knowledge, operational and technical 
capacity of the CCRCC; (ii) support the CCRCC in procuring office and technical equipment to 
assist its day-to-day operations (including information and communications technology hardware 
and software, and office furniture, as needed); (iii) develop guidelines on climate risk assessment, 
climate-related  financial  risk  management,  and  monitoring  and  evaluation  to  track  the 
effectiveness of adaptation measures and pathways for NDC reporting; and (iv) based on these 
guidelines, provide training for trainers on climate risk assessment; climate-related financial risk 
management; gender mainstreaming; and monitoring, reporting, and verification to guide project 
officers in effective NDC reporting and valuation of climate adaptation projects. 
 
8.  Output 2: Guidance for integrating Nationally Determined Contribution adaptation 
targets into policies, strategic planning, and projects developed. Under output 2, activities 
will include (i) identify suitable adaptation measures to be prioritized in the three subsectors, (a) 
water resources management, (b) biodiversity conservation and ecosystem restoration, and (c) 
ecotourism, in alignment with ADB's lending portfolio; 20 (ii) develop pre-feasibility studies that can 
lead to a pipeline of projects in selected aimags (provinces), to strengthen public policies for 
climate change adaptation and promote blended finance mechanisms;21 (iii) design a capacity-
building program for national climate focal points and ministerial representatives (including in 
water,  environment,  agriculture,  and  finance)  on  conducting  climate  vulnerability  and  NDC 
adaptation  assessments  and  mainstreaming  gender  in  adaptation  projects,  report  on  the 
implementation of NDCs and prepare biennial transparency reports in compliance with the 
monitoring, reporting, and verification arrangements under the Paris Agreement;22 (iv) integrate 
NDC adaptation targets into comprehensive land management and local adaptation plans of 
selected aimags in project areas; and (v) share lessons learned with other development partners 
and ADB developing member countries. 
 
9.  Output 3: Environmental civil society organizations engaged in the design and 
implementation of adaptation initiatives. Under output 3, activities will include (i) procedures 
for selecting, awarding, monitoring, and evaluating CSO initiatives to be funded23 in selected 
aimags in three subsectors will be developed;24 (ii) the CCRCC and ADB will jointly publish and 
manage the call for proposals and will form a steering committee to screen, select, and award the 
CSO initiatives; (iii) the CCRCC will engage a selected batch of CSOs in the development of a 
pipeline of adaptation projects under output 3; and (iv) ADB Youth for Asia and its network of

10.  Added value. The TA will create synergies with ADB's lending portfolio in Mongolia, 
including the Sustainable Tourism Development Project (Phase 2);26 and the Aimags and Soums 
Green  Regional  Development  Investment  Program.27 The  TA  will  also  generate  regional 
knowledge spillover under a One ADB approach with other initiatives, such as the NDC Advance 
platform,28 the Regional Flyway Initiative, and the Natural Capital Lab.29 The TA activities will 
mainly contribute to operational priority 3 of ADB’s Strategy 2030: tackling climate change, 
building  climate  and  disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing  environmental  sustainability;  and 
operational priority 2: accelerating progress in gender equality.30  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,100,000, of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 7), and (ii) $600,000 will be financed 
on  a  grant  basis  by the  Climate  Change  Fund.31 The  key  expenditure  items  are  listed  in 
Appendix 2. 
 
12.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of remuneration and travel 
expenses of counterpart staff, access to relevant government data and studies for the TA 
consultants’ use, use of meeting rooms, access to internet, office facilities for counterpart staff, 
provisions of studies and documents for the TA activities, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will administer the TA. The Environment, Natural Resources and Agriculture Division 
of ADB’s East Asia Department will coordinate the implementation of the TA in close collaboration 
with the Mongolia Resident Mission and the Sustainable Development and Climate Change 
Department.  ADB  will  select,  supervise,  and  evaluate  the  TA  consultants  throughout 
TA implementation. 
 
14.  MET will be the executing agency and provide oversight, coordination, and guidance for 
the  TA  implementation.  The  CCRCC  will  serve  as  the  implementing  agency  and  will  be 
responsible for coordination of the TA activities and delivery of outputs and liaison with other
